bibl.title: Bunnell and Bunnell v. Isbell. Defendant Statement
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image.

org.orgName: United States District Court For The Western District of Washington Northern Division

div1.p: In the District of the Territory of Washington, and for the First Judicial District thereof, holidng terms at the City of Colfax, in and for the County of Whitman, said Territory.
In the matter of the Application of Edgar Bunnell and Arthur Bunnell for Writ of Habeas Corpus.
Comes now William Isbell, and in answer to the order to show cause in above proceeding, and as a return to the Writ issued, avers:

That at all the times in the petition mentioned, Thomas Kennedy was a duly elected, qualified and acting Justice of the Peace in and for Precinct Number 4,1/2 in the County of Whitman, Territory of Washington, and that said precinct embraced within its limits the whole of the Town of Garfield in the petition herein described, and that this affiant was the duly qualified and acting Mashal of said Town of Garfield. That on the firsst day of September, A.D., 1888, a complaint in writing was duly sworn to by I.N. Stockton and filed with said Thomas Kennedy, charging said Edgar Bunnell and Arthur Bunnell with beig drunk and disorderly and with violating Section "12" of ordinance "8" of said Town, and that a warrant was issued thereon and said parties were arrested and brought before said Thomas Kennedy as Justice of the peace, and were duly tried and convicted and fined inthe sum of $15-- each and were adjudged to pay the costs of said action amounting to $65.80, and it was ordered that execution issue on said judgment.
That on the 11th day of September, A.D., 1888, the said judgement being in full force and effect, the said Edgar Bunnell and Arthur Bunnell gave the followin Bond:
Whereas a Judgment in the above entitled cause against defendants
